articles.headline: Russian Fund Under Scrutiny for Loan to Company Linked to Kremlin
articles.snippet: The government-backed Russian Direct Investment Fund is in the spotlight for making a big loan to Sibur, two of whose major owners have ties to President Vladimir Putin.
articles.abstract: The government-backed Russian Direct Investment Fund is in the spotlight for making a big loan to Sibur, two of whose major owners have ties to President Vladimir Putin.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — When a new government-backed investment fund opened five years ago, Moscow wanted to send a simple message: Russia was ready to take the politics out of business.

articles.headline: Russians’ Anxiety Swells as Oil Prices Collapse
articles.snippet: Strikes and protests by workers have cropped up as the Russian government cut salaries and subsidies in response to plunging oil revenues.
articles.abstract: Strikes and protests by workers have cropped up as the Russian government cut salaries and subsidies in response to plunging oil revenues.
articles.lead_paragraph: KRASNODAR, Russia — Last year was bad enough financially for Sergei and Victoria Titov, both music teachers getting along in years. Her government salary was slashed by one third, and rampant inflation put some basic groceries like eggplant and cucumbers out of reach.

articles.headline: Takata Airbag Flaw Linked to 10th Death; 5 Million More Vehicles Recalled
articles.snippet: Regulators said the latest death, in a Ford pickup, was the first Takata-related fatality in a non-Honda vehicle.
articles.abstract: Regulators said the latest death, in a Ford pickup, was the first Takata-related fatality in a non-Honda vehicle.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal safety regulators on Friday said that a man had died in late December when an airbag made by Takata exploded in the vehicle he was driving.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Danielle Ivory

articles.headline: Academy Board Endorses Changes to Increase Diversity in Oscar Nominees and Itself
articles.snippet: Stung by criticism of its all-white Oscar nominations, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said it would overhaul its structure to increase diversity.
articles.abstract: Stung by criticism of its all-white Oscar nominations, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said it would overhaul its structure to increase diversity.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Confronting a fierce protest over a second straight year of all-white Oscar acting nominations, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said on Friday that it would make radical changes to its voting requirements, recruiting process and governing structure, with an aim toward increasing the diversity of its membership.

articles.headline: Robo-Advisers for Investors Are Not One-Size-Fits-All
articles.snippet: Robo-advisers run on autopilot, cost a fraction of traditional advisers’ fees and are usually available to small investors, but the risk approaches vary.
articles.abstract: Robo-advisers run on autopilot, cost a fraction of traditional advisers’ fees and are usually available to small investors, but the risk approaches vary.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since the last major stock market plunge, back in 2008 and 2009, a new type of investment adviser has arrived on the scene.

articles.headline: The Timeshare Hard Sell Comes Roaring Back
articles.snippet: High-pressure practices by Diamond and others have prompted lawsuits and led to predictions that regulators will increase oversight of the industry.
articles.abstract: High-pressure practices by Diamond and others have prompted lawsuits and led to predictions that regulators will increase oversight of the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: For more than 25 years, Mary Ann Gutierrez, 77, has spent several weeks a year at on the southern shore of Lake Tahoe, Calif., often playing host to her children and grandchildren at one of two timeshare units she owns.

articles.headline: Fears About China’s Economy Fester at Davos
articles.snippet: As fingers point to China as a source of economic concern, its supporters note its potential for growth.
articles.abstract: As fingers point to China as a source of economic concern, its supporters note its potential for growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — At the World Economic Forum here, chief executives and investors are blaming China for a slump in global markets.

articles.headline: Their Boss Stays on the Sideline, but Obama Aides Tilt to Clinton
articles.snippet: The White House is working with Hillary Clinton’s campaign in ways large and small. Their two staffs consult on issues and the positions she takes on the president’s policy priorities.
articles.abstract: The White House is working with Hillary Clinton’s campaign in ways large and small. Their two staffs consult on issues and the positions she takes on the president’s policy priorities.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The two leading Democratic contenders for president are competing to wrap President Obama in a tight embrace. He is hugging only one of them back.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler, Amy Chozick and Jason Horowitz

articles.headline: Clues Emerge on Robert Levinson, C.I.A. Consultant Who Vanished in Iran
articles.snippet: Newly disclosed documents conflict with Iran’s claim it knew nothing about the consultant Mr. Levinson who disappeared in Iran in 2007.
articles.abstract: Newly disclosed documents conflict with Iran’s claim it knew nothing about the consultant Mr. Levinson who disappeared in Iran in 2007.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the United States and Iran swapped prisoners last week, nothing was said to resolve the mystery about another captive: Robert A. Levinson, a Central Intelligence Agency consultant who disappeared in Iran in 2007.

articles.headline: As Frustrations With Mexico’s Government Rise, So Do Lynchings
articles.snippet: The actions are born of a sense of hopelessness and impotence in the country, where 98 percent of murders go unsolved and many crimes are not even reported.
articles.abstract: The actions are born of a sense of hopelessness and impotence in the country, where 98 percent of murders go unsolved and many crimes are not even reported.
articles.lead_paragraph: AJALPAN, Mexico — The lynching began around 7:20 p.m., not long after the brothers had finished conducting their final interviews on tortilla consumption.
articles.byline: By Azam Ahmed and Paulina Villegas

articles.headline: U.S. Relies Heavily on Saudi Money to Support Syrian Rebels
articles.snippet: A joint arming and training program between the C.I.A. and Saudi Arabia reflects the enduring alliance between the nations even as their relationship and the kingdom’s place in the region are in flux.
articles.abstract: A joint arming and training program between the C.I.A. and Saudi Arabia reflects the enduring alliance between the nations even as their relationship and the kingdom’s place in the region are in flux.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama secretly authorized the Central Intelligence Agency to begin arming Syria’s embattled rebels in 2013, the spy agency knew it would have a willing partner to help pay for the covert operation. It was the same partner the C.I.A. has relied on for decades for money and discretion in far-off conflicts: the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: When the Water Turned Brown
articles.snippet: As every major decision was made over more than a year, officials at all levels of government acted in ways that contributed to the public health emergency in Flint, Mich.
articles.abstract: As every major decision was made over more than a year, officials at all levels of government acted in ways that contributed to the public health emergency in Flint, Mich.
articles.lead_paragraph: FLINT, Mich. — Standing at a microphone in September holding up a baby bottle, Dr. Mona Hanna-Attisha, a local pediatrician, said she was deeply worried about the water. The number of Flint children with elevated levels of lead in their blood had risen alarmingly since the city changed its water supply the previous year, her analysis showed.
articles.byline: By Abby Goodnough, Monica Davey and Mitch Smith

articles.headline: Bernie Sanders Courts Elusive Voters: Young Iowans
articles.snippet: Mr. Sanders has struck a chord with young people, but his campaign acknowledges that beating Hillary Clinton in Iowa will require overcoming their history of dismal attendance.
articles.abstract: Mr. Sanders has struck a chord with young people, but his campaign acknowledges that beating Hillary Clinton in Iowa will require overcoming their history of dismal attendance.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNDERWOOD, Iowa — With the Iowa caucuses just over a week away, the Bernie Sanders youth brigade is on the move.
articles.byline: By Jason Horowitz and Yamiche Alcindor

articles.headline: Looking for Signs That Apple’s Runaway Growth Is Waning
articles.snippet: With iPhone sales projected to decelerate, investors will be scouring Apple’s earnings report on Tuesday for signs of how fast the company’s downshift is happening.
articles.abstract: With iPhone sales projected to decelerate, investors will be scouring Apple’s earnings report on Tuesday for signs of how fast the company’s downshift is happening.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Investors have long relied on Apple to deliver one crucial attribute: growth. Now they are beginning to wonder whether Apple’s days as a growth stock are coming to an end.

articles.headline: Massachusetts Chief’s Tack in Drug War: Steer Addicts to Rehab, Not Jail
articles.snippet: Approaching addiction as a disease, the Gloucester Police Department became the unusual law enforcement agency offering heroin users an alternative to prison.
articles.abstract: Approaching addiction as a disease, the Gloucester Police Department became the unusual law enforcement agency offering heroin users an alternative to prison.
articles.lead_paragraph: CANTON, Ohio — Leonard Campanello, the police chief of Gloucester, Mass., took the microphone here in mid-December and opened with his usual warm-up line: I’m from Gloucester, he said in his heavy Boston accent. “That’s spelled ‘G-l-o-s-t-a-h.’”

articles.headline: Europe’s Top Digital-Privacy Watchdog Zeros In on U.S. Tech Giants
articles.snippet: Whether or not negotiators reach a pact by Feb. 1 on how companies like Google and Facebook use Europeans’ online data, Isabelle Falque-Pierrotin is in a position to propel privacy protection efforts.
articles.abstract: Whether or not negotiators reach a pact by Feb. 1 on how companies like Google and Facebook use Europeans’ online data, Isabelle Falque-Pierrotin is in a position to propel privacy protection efforts.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The latest standoff between Europe and American tech companies runs through a quiet street just north of the Louvre Museum, past chic cafes and part of the French national library, to the ornate office of Isabelle Falque-Pierrotin.

articles.headline: Italy Divided Over Effort to Legalize Civil Unions for Gays
articles.snippet: Years after a similar effort failed, lawmakers are confronting an issue that remains a wide divide between Italy and most of the rest of the West.
articles.abstract: Years after a similar effort failed, lawmakers are confronting an issue that remains a wide divide between Italy and most of the rest of the West.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — Six years ago, Andrea Rubera married his partner in Canada, where the couple later became parents of three young children. But when they returned to their native Italy, a transformation occurred. Mr. Rubera suddenly became a single man, and his legally recognized husband in Canada became his single male roommate in Italy. Italian law also divided custody of their children.

articles.headline: A Struggle to Quell Investor Fears Over Unsettled Emerging Markets
articles.snippet: Traders and portfolio managers worry that sophisticated institutional investors, who generally tend to take a longer-term view, have been the ones driving the selling over the last six months.
articles.abstract: Traders and portfolio managers worry that sophisticated institutional investors, who generally tend to take a longer-term view, have been the ones driving the selling over the last six months.
articles.lead_paragraph: Currency turmoil in China and fears of a global slowdown have led investors to abandon emerging markets in droves, rattling the large asset management firms that have long promoted such investments in their hunt for higher returns.

articles.headline: Second-Year Super Bowl Advertisers Face Their Own Pressures to Succeed
articles.snippet: Avocados From Mexico and at least two other advertisers, Skittles and Wix.com, have decided to return to the Super Bowl, indicating that live television remains important for advertisers.
articles.abstract: Avocados From Mexico and at least two other advertisers, Skittles and Wix.com, have decided to return to the Super Bowl, indicating that live television remains important for advertisers.
articles.lead_paragraph: To say Alvaro Luque, the president of Avocados From Mexico, was nervous during last year’s Super Bowl would be an understatement. His company had decided to advertise during the game for the first time, and millions of dollars were at stake.

articles.headline: Employee Wellness Programs Use Carrots and, Increasingly, Sticks
articles.snippet: Workers at many companies now face stiff financial penalties for refusing to undergo health screenings.
articles.abstract: Workers at many companies now face stiff financial penalties for refusing to undergo health screenings.
articles.lead_paragraph: It may be an offer employees simply can no longer refuse.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Battle for Party’s Future
articles.snippet: With many Democrats torn between pragmatism and liberalism, the question of whether the party’s left wing can become a true force again in presidential politics will soon have its first test, in Iowa.
articles.abstract: With many Democrats torn between pragmatism and liberalism, the question of whether the party’s left wing can become a true force again in presidential politics will soon have its first test, in Iowa.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — The race between Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders, which voters will begin deciding a week from Monday, is not just about the White House anymore. It has intensified into an epochal battle over their vastly different visions for the Democratic Party.

articles.headline: Donald Trump Means Business in Iowa: Night in Motel, and a Day in Church
articles.snippet: Donald Trump, who has said he really wants to win Iowa, is laser-focused on it as the caucuses draw near, even sleeping in a Holiday Inn Express and showing up for church services.
articles.abstract: Donald Trump, who has said he really wants to win Iowa, is laser-focused on it as the caucuses draw near, even sleeping in a Holiday Inn Express and showing up for church services.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUSCATINE, Iowa — Donald J. Trump spent the last seven months saying he wanted to win. Now he is really acting like it.

articles.headline: Iran’s Sanctions Lift, and the West Goes to Talk Business
articles.snippet: Airbus orders, likely to be partly financed with loans from European export-credit agencies, could be announced as early as this week, an official said.
articles.abstract: Airbus orders, likely to be partly financed with loans from European export-credit agencies, could be announced as early as this week, an official said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Airbus said Monday it was in talks with Iran toward the sale of dozens of new commercial aircraft — part of a number of international business deals likely to flow toward Iran since it agreed to curtail its nuclear ambitions.
articles.byline: By Nicola Clark and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Tyco Merger Will Shift Johnson Controls’ Tax Liability Overseas
articles.snippet: With its domicile in Ireland, the merged company will be able to save about $150 million in taxes a year.
articles.abstract: With its domicile in Ireland, the merged company will be able to save about $150 million in taxes a year.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the first big mergers of the new year resembles a number of other deals in recent years in one crucial respect: It will allow an American corporation to move its headquarters to a country where corporate taxes are lower.

articles.headline: Before Rise as Outsider, Ted Cruz Played Inside Role in 2000 Recount
articles.snippet: His initial venture into presidential politics both installed Mr. Cruz as a creature of the Republican establishment and helped begin his divorce from it.
articles.abstract: His initial venture into presidential politics both installed Mr. Cruz as a creature of the Republican establishment and helped begin his divorce from it.
articles.lead_paragraph: In late November 2000, with senior aides to George W. Bush holed up in Tallahassee, Fla., navigating the thickets of election law, a 29-year-old domestic policy adviser named Ted Cruz was given a humbling task: Walk a stack of papers to Federal District Court.
